Award.AwardTitle: Role of Subcortical Systems in Hippocampal Memory Processing
Award.AbstractNarration: The ultimate goal of this project is to understand mechanisms responsible for memory processing in the brain. Although several factors contribute to the formation of memories, it is well recognized that the encoding of information in the brain depends on two critical processes: attention and meaning. In effect, events are best remembered when they are attended to and when they are meaningful. In mammals, it is further generally acknowledged that information is initially stored in the hippocampus of the brain. In previous studies using the rat model, the investigator identified a system of connections in the brain that generate the so called theta rhythm of the hippocampus, which appears to serve a direct role in the encoding of significant (or meaningful) information in the hippocampus. Specifically, the hippocampus receives information from various regions of the cortex, and theta may serve to amplify information bearing signals from the cortex, leading to their storage in the hippocampus. In a similar manner, another system of inputs to the hippocampus from the midline thalamus has been identified that appears to code for the dimension of attention to environmental events. This project will, in part, examine the effects of selective activation (or inactivation) of inputs to the hippocampus that are responsible for attention and meaning in memory processing in this structure. More specifically, the manner and degree to which these manipulations will enhance (or impede) learning and memory in rats will be examined. These studies should significantly contribute to an understanding of mechanisms of memory formation in the brain. The researcher engages undergraduate and graduate students in his research projects and continues to disseminate his experimental findings in various professional and lay forums.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goals of the project were to understand the role of major subcortical inputs to the hippocampus in hippocampal memory processing. These included the medial septum, the supramammillary nucleus and the nucleus reuniens of the midline thalamus – with a concentration on the midline thalamus. The basic framework for this work is that the entorhinal cortex is the source of ‘information bearing’ input to the hippocampus and the subcortical afferents to the hippocampus mainly serve to modulate/control access of that information to the hippocampus for its short and long term storage. By gating information transfer to the hippocampus, the subcortical structures might represent the neural substrates for processes such as attention and value; that is, information that is attended to and of significance to an organism tends to be preferentially remembered over that which is not. 

 

To this end, we have shown that the nucleus reuniens of the midline thalamus has pronounced reciprocal projections with the hippocampus and the medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC) and that approximately 5-10% of cells of nucleus reuniens (RE) project to both the hippocampus and the mPFC via axon collaterals (or branching axons) indicating that RE is positioned to simultaneously influence these two major structures involved in memory processing in the brain. This population of RE cells may be involved in the transfer of information from the hippocampus to the mPFC for its permanent storage. In this regard, we (and others) have recently shown that damage (or reversible or irreversible lesions) of nucleus reuniens significantly alters behavior in those tasks that specifically involve interactions between the hippocampus and the mPFC.  In separate studies, we have further demonstrated that the nucleus reuniens and its target structure, the mPFC, receive pronounced input from serotonin containing cells of the brainstem, indicating that serotonergic fibers are positioned to exert an indirect (via nucleus reuniens) and a direct influence on the medial prefrontal cortex. The serotonergic input to the nucleus reuniens may represent a model network in which various afferent systems subserving arousal/attentional mechanisms converge on nucleus reuniens and, RE, in turn, exerts modulatory influences on the hippocampus and prefrontal cortex related to the attentive state of the organism. 

 

Although increasingly more attention is being paid to nucleus reuniens and its role in memory, the lab of the PI is still one of the few investigating the properties of nucleus reuniens -- and other nuclei of the midline thalamus. The PI, together with Dr. Jean-Christophe Cassel of Strasbourg, France, recently published a comprehensive review of the nucleus reuniens and the dorsally adjacent rhomboid nucleus entitled: “The reuniens and rhomboid nuclei: neuroanatomy, electrophysiological characteristics and behavioral implications”. Progress in Neurobiology 111: 34-52, 2013.

 

Since the nucleus reuniens represents an important hub in communication to, and between, the hippocampus and mPFC, it appears to serve a vital role in human disorders involving these two structures. Accordingly, nucleus reuniens has been strongly linked to several disorders including Alzheimer’s disease, schizophrenia and epilepsy.
